text: Standard 1: Students understand and use basic and advanced concepts of number and number systems.

children.text: Numbers, Number Relationships, and Number Systems
Count to 20
Count backward from 10 to 1
Demonstrate one-to-one correspondence by  counting up to 10 objects
Identify ordinal numbers to order objects, 1<sup>st</sup> -  5<sup>th</sup>
Identify and write numerals to 10
Determine the relationship between two sets  with 10 or fewer objects, i.e., less than, greater  than, or equal to
Use concrete materials to represent wholes  and halves
Count and order numbers to 100
Identify and write numerals to 100
Count backward from 20
Count by 2's to 20, and 10's to 100
Group objects by 2's, 5's, and 10's
Identify position using ordinal numbers
Connect number words and numerals to the  quantities they represent (0 - 10)
Represent and explain fractions (i.e., one half,  one fourth) as part of a whole and part of a set  using concrete materials/drawings
Identify place value for ones and tens
Compare two digit numbers using symbols,  i.e., >, <, =
Use grade-appropriate terms when  communicating about addition and subtraction,  i.e., sum, difference
Count and order numbers up to 1,000
Count backward from 100
Count by 2's, 5's, and 10's
Identify and write numerals to 1,000
Connect number words and numerals to the  quantities they represent up to 100
Demonstrate, identify, and explain the  difference between odd and even numbers  using concrete objects or drawings
Identify place value concepts through the  hundreds place
Use symbols (i.e., >, <, =) to compare whole  numbers to 1,000
Round numbers to tens and hundreds
Use grade-appropriate terms when  communicating about addition and subtraction,  i.e., addend, sum, difference
Represent and explain fractions (i.e., one half,  one third, one fourth, one sixth and one eighth)  as part of a whole and part of a set
Count and order numbers up to 10,000
Read and write numerals to 10,000
Represent numbers up to 10,000 in standard,  expanded, and word form
Identify the odd and even whole numbers from  0 to 10,000
Identify place values from ten-thousands  through the hundredths place
Use symbols to compare whole numbers from  0 to 10,000, i.e., >, <, =
Use mathematical terms when communicating  about computations, i.e., factor, product,  divisor, dividend, quotient
Round numbers to tens, hundreds, and  thousands
Represent fractions and mixed numbers using  words, numerals, and physical models
Model, represent, and explain the concept of  multiplication, i.e., repeated addition,  rectangular arrays, and skip counting
Model, represent, and explain the concept of  division, i.e., repeated subtraction, rectangular  arrays, and equal sharing
Use a variety of methods and tools for problem  solving, e.g., computing, including mental  math, paper and pencil, calculator,  manipulatives
Identify place value from hundred thousands  through the hundredths place
Order and compare using symbols, i.e., >, <,  =, whole numbers (0 to 100,000) and decimals  to hundredths
Read and write numerals to 100,000
Round whole numbers to the nearest tens,  hundreds, thousands, ten thousands, and  hundred thousands
Represent numbers up to hundred thousands  in standard and expanded forms
Write tenths and hundredths as decimals and  fractions
Compare equivalent decimals and fractions,  e.g. 5/10 = .5
Use mathematical terms when communicating  about computations involving fractions, i.e.,  numerator and denominator
Explain the meaning of remainders in realworld  situations
Determine what information is relevant for  solving a problem
Use a variety of strategies to solve problems,  e.g., guess and check, work backwards, draw  pictures, use objects
Identify place value from the billions through  the thousandths place
Order and compare whole numbers using  symbols
Round whole numbers to the nearest million
Read and represent numbers to 1,000,000 in  standard, expanded, and short word form
Place integers on a number line
Use negative integers in real-world situations,  e.g., thermometer reading, yardage in a  football game
Identify prime and composite numbers
Round, order, and compare, using symbols,  fractions with like and unlike denominators
Round, order, and compare, using symbols,  decimals to the tenths, hundredths, and  thousandths place
Explain and demonstrate the concept of a  percent
Compare equivalent fractions, decimals, and  percents, e.g., 75/100 = .75 = 75%
Represent ratios and percents as parts of a  whole using models and pictures
Explain and demonstrate the relationship  between exponential notation and repeated  multiplication, e.g. 3² = 3 x 3
Use a fraction to represent parts of a whole,  division, or a ratio
Explain and use whole number percents 1 to 100
Find the equivalent forms among fractions,  decimals, and whole number percents
Compare and order fractions, decimals, mixed  numbers and integers
Generate a list of factors, prime factors, and  multiples
Use rules to determine divisibility by 2, 3, 5, 6, 9, and 10
Use ratios and proportions to represent  relationships
Explain and use percents greater than 100
Use prime factorization to determine the  greatest common factor and least common  multiple
Use integers to represent and compare  quantities
Identify subsets of the real number system,  i.e., natural and whole numbers, integers,  rational and irrational numbers
Solve real-world problems involving ratio,  proportion, and percent
Identify perfect squares 1 to 144 and  approximate square roots
Represent large and small numbers using  scientific notation
Express numbers between one-billionth  and one billion in fraction, decimal, and  verbal form; express numbers of all  magnitudes in scientific notation
Describe the hierarchal relationships (e.g.,  integers are rationals) among subsets of  the real number system, i.e., reals,  rationals, irrationals, integers, wholes, and  naturals
Identify the properties of the real number  system, i.e., commutative, associative,  distributive, closure, inverse, and identity  properties
Represent a set of data in a matrix
Translate between radical expressions  and expressions involving rational  exponents
Describe the hierarchal relationships (e.g.,  explain why real numbers are complex)  among subsets of the complex number  system, i.e., complex, real, and imaginary
Use imaginary numbers to express  square roots of negative numbers
Justify the steps of an algebraic process  using the properties of the real number  system, e.g., write an algebraic proof
Operations and Their Properties
Use symbols to write addition and subtraction  number sentences, i.e., +, -, =
Select an operation to solve problems  involving addition and subtraction of whole  numbers
Demonstrate the inverse relationship between  addition and subtraction, i.e. 3 + 4 = 7, 7 - 4 = 3
Model multiplication using equal sets of  objects
Add and subtract two-digit whole numbers  between 0 and 100 without regrouping
Add and subtract whole numbers between 0  and 10,000
Model and use the commutative and  associative properties of addition and  multiplication
Apply the multiplication property of zero and  one
Multiply two- and three-digit numbers by a  single-digit number
Divide two- and three-digit numbers by single-digit  number without remainders
Demonstrate the inverse relationships  between multiplication and division
Add and subtract simple fractions with like  denominators, e.g., 1/4 + 2/4 = 3/4
Add and subtract whole numbers between 0  and 100,000
Multiply multi-digit numbers by two-digit  numbers
Divide multi-digit numbers by a single-digit  number
Add and subtract fractions and mixed numbers  with like denominators
Add and subtract decimals
Use the distributive property to simplify and  perform computations
Add and subtract whole numbers between 0 and 1,000,000
Use commutative, associative, and identity  properties to solve problems
Use divisibility rules for 2, 5, and 10
Determine the prime factors for a number  using a factor tree
Determine least common multiple
Determine greatest common factor
Use order of operations to simplify numeric  expressions
Multiply multi-digit numbers by three-digit  numbers
Divide multi-digit numbers by two-digit  numbers with or without remainders
Add and subtract improper fractions and mixed  numbers with unlike denominators
Add and subtract multi-digit decimals
Multiply and divide multi-digit decimals
Explain the effects of arithmetic operations on  fractions and decimals
Identify the uses of the commutative and  associative properties of addition and  multiplication, e.g., grouping numbers to make  addition or multiplication easier
Use order of operations, i.e., multiplication,  division, addition and subtraction, to simplify  numeric expressions
Explain the effects of arithmetic operations on  fractions, decimals, and integers
Use order of operations (i.e., parentheses and  operations) to simplify numeric expressions
Apply operation properties to simplify  computations and solve problems, i.e.,  commutative, associative, and distributive
Apply the order of operations to simplify  numeric expressions and solve problems
Use the order of operations and  properties of exponents to simplify an  algebraic expression

Analyze the effects of multiplication,  division, raising to a power, and extracting  a root on the magnitudes of quantities,  e.g., when will the square root of a  number be greater than the number itself,  or what will happen to the magnitude of a  number when you multiply it by a negative  number?
Apply basic properties of exponents to  simplify algebraic expressions, i.e., power  of a product, power of a power, products  and quotients of powers, zero and  negative exponents
Determine which properties of the real  number system hold for matrices, e.g.,  matrix multiplication is not commutative

Apply basic properties of exponents and  logarithms to rewrite algebraic  expressions, i.e., power of a product,  power of a power, products and quotients  of powers, zero and negative exponents,  and log of a product, quotient, or power
Computational Fluency and Estimation
Recall addition facts and subtraction facts (0-10)
Estimate the number of objects and check by  counting
Recall addition facts and subtraction facts (0 - 18)
Estimate whole number sums and differences
Recall multiplication and division facts (0-10)
Estimate whole number products and  quotients
Use estimation to determine if solutions are  reasonable
Determine when a rounded solution is  appropriate
Estimate computations of whole numbers,  fractions, and decimals
Multiply and divide decimals
Add, subtract, multiply, and divide fractions
Express an exponent in standard form
Use problem solving strategies to solve and  verify the results of problems
Estimate the results of problems involving  whole numbers, fractions, and decimals
Add, subtract, multiply, and divide fractions  and terminating decimals
Solve real-world problems using integers,  fractions, decimals, and percents
Estimate the results of problems involving  fractions, decimals, and percents
Use proportions to solve problems
Add, subtract, multiply, and divide integers
Select and use a computational technique  (e.g., mental calculation, paper-and-pencil,  technology) to solve problems
Determine when an estimate is sufficient and  an exact answer is needed in problem  situations
Apply estimation skills to predict realistic  solutions to problems
Select and use a computational technique  (i.e., mental calculation, paper-and-pencil,  or technology) to solve problems involving  real numbers
Explain the reasonableness of a  problem's solution and the process used  to obtain it
Add, subtract, and perform scalar  multiplication on matrices
Add, subtract, and multiply complex  numbers
Multiply matrices containing no more than  three rows or columns without the use of  technology

text: Standard 2: Students understand and apply geometric concepts and spatial relationships to represent and solve problems in mathematical and nonmathematical situations.

children.text: Two- and Three-Dimensional Shapes, Geometric Properties and Relationships
Identify and reproduce two-dimensional  figures, i.e. circle, triangle, rectangle and  square
Match a three-dimensional object with its  stated name, i.e. cone, sphere, cube, cylinder  (e.g. which of these is a cone?)
Identify, compare, draw and sort two-dimensional  figures, i.e. circle, triangle,  rectangle, square, oval, and diamond
Identify three-dimensional objects, i.e.  pyramid, cube, cone, cylinder, sphere
Recognize geometric shapes and structures in  their environment
Identify, describe and sort three-dimensional  objects, i.e. pyramid, cube, rectangular prism,  cone, cylinder and sphere
Predict and demonstrate the results of putting  together and taking apart shapes
Compare physical attributes of two-dimensional  shapes, i.e. square, triangle,  rectangle and parallelogram
Describe the characteristics of a cylinder,  pyramid, cube, sphere and cone
Identify points, endpoints, lines, line segments,  rays and angles and use symbols to represent  them
Identify right angles
Analyze and describe the attributes of two- and  three-dimensional shapes (i.e. circle,  squares, trapezoid, rhombus)
Identify, describe and model (e.g. using  straws or other materials) parallel,  perpendicular and intersecting lines and line  segments

Describe properties and attributes of two- and three-dimensional figures, i.e. obtuse angle, acute angle, radius, chord, diagonal, equilateral triangle, isosceles triangle, parallel lines, perpendicular lines
Draw circles using a compass and identify the components, i.e. radius, chord, diameter, center and circumference
Identify the attributes of an angle and draw angles using protractors
Determine the degrees of the interior angles of triangles and quadrilaterals
Determine the characteristics of and the relationships among points, lines, line segments, rays and planes
Identify relationships between pairs of angles,  i.e. adjacent, vertical, complementary and  supplementary
Identify polygons, i.e. triangle, rectangle,  square, rhombus, parallelogram, trapezoid,  pentagon, hexagon, octagon
Describe the characteristics of a right triangle
Make observations about relationships  between two- and three-dimensional figures,  e.g. a cube is made with six squares
Classify triangles based on side and angle  measurements, i.e. scalene, isosceles,  equilateral, acute, obtuse and right
Use nets to represent the relationships  between two- and three-dimensional figures
Classify quadrilaterals based on side lengths,  angle measures and sets of parallel sides
Identify the angles formed and the  relationships between the angles when parallel  lines are intersected by a transversal
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to problems  involving right triangles
Identify the properties and attributes of  two- and three-dimensional objects that  distinguish one from another, e.g. a  cylinder has two parallel circular bases
Determine congruence and similarity  among geometric objects
Use trigonometric relationships and the  Pythagorean Theorem to determine side  lengths and angle measures in right  triangles
Using given information, establish the  validity of a conjecture using a two-column  or paragraph proof
Use trigonometric relationships to  determine side lengths and angle  measures in triangles, i.e. right triangle  trigonometry, Law of Sines and Law of Cosines
Coordinate Geometry
Use ordered pairs to identify the locations of  points in a grid, e.g. A-10 on a map
Use ordered pairs in quadrant 1 of a coordinate grid
Use ordered pairs to locate a point on a  coordinate plane
Draw and label the components of the  coordinate plane, i.e. coordinates, quadrants,  origin, x- and y-axes
Represent shapes using coordinate geometry
Use Cartesian coordinates to determine  distance, midpoint and slope

Use distance, midpoint and slope to  determine relationships between points,  lines and plane figures in the Cartesian  coordinate system, e.g. determine  whether a triangle is scalene, isosceles,  or equilateral given the coordinates of its  vertices
Transformation and Symmetry
Identify lines of symmetry in two-dimensional  figures
Identify symmetrical shapes and draw their  line of symmetry
Identify congruent figures from a selection of  similar figures
Identify and create shapes that have lines of  symmetry
Identify two-dimensional shapes that are  congruent or similar
Recognize the changes in position and  orientation of two-dimensional figures after  transformations, i.e. flips (reflections), turns  (rotations) and slides (translations)
Use motion geometry to show that shapes are  congruent or similar
Describe properties of congruent figures and use them to solve problems
Identify, describe and model motion  geometry, i.e. rotations, reflections and  translations
Identify relationships between congruent  figures and similar figures
Draw the result of a transformation in the  coordinate plane, i.e. translation, reflection  and rotation
Draw the results of a combination of  transformations in the coordinate plane, i.e.  reflections, rotations and translations
Use scale, proportion and congruency to  solve problems involving similar figures
Identify and perform transformations of  objects in the plane using sketches  (translations, reflections, rotations and  dilations) and coordinates (translations,  reflections and dilations)
Describe the effects of combining basic  transformations in a plane, e.g. two  reflections over parallel lines results in a  translation
Visualization, Spatial Reasoning, and Geometric Modeling
Identify position and direction, i.e. inside,  outside, between, above, below, behind, left,  and right
Arrange and describe objects in space by  proximity, position and direction, e.g. near,  far, below, above, up, down, behind, in front  of, next to, left or right of
Draw basic geometric figures using  appropriate tools, i.e. circle with a compass,  triangle and rectangle with a ruler or straight  edge
Build and sketch three-dimensional solids,  e.g. using nets, manipulatives
Use two-dimensional representations of three-dimensional  objects to visualize and solve  problems, e.g. those involving surface area  and volume
Construct plane figures using traditional  and/or technological tools, i.e. congruent  segments, congruent angles, angle and  segment bisectors, perpendicular and  parallel lines
Recognize images of the same object  shown from different perspectives, i.e. a  two-dimensional image of a three-dimensional  object
Use geometric models to find solutions to  problems in mathematics and other  disciplines, e.g. art and architecture

text: Standard 3: Students use data collection and analysis techniques, statistical methods, and probability to solve problems.

children.text: Data Collection, Display, and Interpretation
Sort objects according to a given attribute,  e.g. use, size, color, shape
Read and interpret picture graphs as sources  of information
Identify and display various forms of data in  their world using charts and graphs, e.g. tally  charts and bar graphs
Read and interpret tally charts and picture  graphs as sources of information
Sort objects by common attribute
Sort and classify objects according to their  attributes and organize data about the objects,  e.g. Venn diagrams, graphs, tables
Demonstrate that data can be represented in a  variety of ways
Formulate and answer simple questions from  data represented by graphs
Identify different parts of a graph, i.e. label,  scale and data
Display and interpret graphs with symbols or  pictures that represent more than one object  or event
Solve problems based on data displayed on a  graph
Recognize the elements in the union and  intersection of sets represented by Venn  diagrams
Determine a sample group to survey
Collect and record data
Organize and display data in line graphs and  circle graphs
Read, interpret and generate questions from  data displayed in graphs, i.e. line graphs and  circle graphs
Use computers and spreadsheets to organize  and display data
Use number lines and coordinate graphs to  represent data
Read and interpret bar, line and circle graphs,  pictographs and frequency tables
Collect and organize data, select and use an  appropriate display, i.e. a frequency table, a  line and bar graph
Formulate a question; collect, organize and  display data using a bar, line and circle graph
Formulate a question and select a random or  representative sample
Collect, organize and display data using  scatter and stem-and-leaf plot
Construct appropriate displays of given  data, i.e. circle graphs, bar graphs,  histograms, stem-and-leaf plots, box-and-whisker  plots and scatter plots
Interpret a given visual representation  (i.e. circle graphs, bar graphs,  histograms, stem-and-leaf plots, box-and-whisker  plots and scatter plots) of a set of  data

Identify the variable, sample and  population in a well-designed study, e.g.  in an exit poll for a tax increase, the  variable is the outcome of the vote, the  sample is the set of people surveyed, the  population is the set of all voters
Choose, construct and interpret a display  to represent a set of data
Probability
Use a simple probability experiment to collect  data, display the data in a graph, and interpret  the likelihood of the outcome
Conduct simple probability experiments
Determine the probability of a simple event  and express it as a ratio
State possible outcomes for a given situation
Determine possible arrangements of four or  fewer items
Count possible outcomes using lists
Use experiments or simulations to determine  probabilities
Use decimal values and ratios to represent  probability
Determine possible outcomes using organized  lists, tree diagrams or Venn diagrams
Formulate hypotheses, conduct probability  experiments and draw conclusions from  results
Compute probabilities for simple events
Determine possible outcomes using organized  lists, tree diagrams, Venn diagrams, factorials  and the basic counting principle
Distinguish between experimental and  theoretical probability, i.e. the results of an  experiment may not match the theoretical  probability
Determine the number of possible  outcomes for a given event, using  appropriate counting techniques, e.g.  fundamental counting principle, factorials,  combinations, permutations
Calculate experimental and theoretical  probabilities with and without replacement
Calculate probabilities of compound  events using addition and multiplication  rules
Make predictions based on theoretical  probabilities and experimental results
Statistical Methods
Determine or calculate the mode,  mean/average and range for a data set
Determine or calculate the mode, mean and  range of a set of data
Calculate the mean, median, mode and range of a set of data
Calculate and compare information provided  by the mean, median, mode and range of a  set of data
Calculate and compare the measures of  central tendency (i.e. mean, median, mode)  and spread (i.e. range)
Identify an outlier within a set of data and  discuss its effects on the measures of central  tendency and spread
Calculate measures of central tendency  and spread, i.e. mean, median, mode,  range and quartiles
Discuss relationships among measures of  central tendency and spread, i.e. mean,  median, mode, range and quartiles
Select, calculate and use appropriate  measures of central tendency and spread  (i.e. mean, median, mode, range and  quartiles) to draw meaningful conclusions  about a set of data
Predictions, Data Analysis, and Inferences
Record results of activities involving chance  (e.g. coin flips, dice rolls) and make  reasonable predictions based upon data
Describe the likelihood of an event, e.g.  cloudy, it may rain
Determine which outcomes are most likely to  occur in certain situations, e.g. spinning red is  most likely to occur when the spinner is  divided among red, blue, green, red
Make predictions and draw conclusions from  simple probability experiments
Make predictions and draw conclusions based  on data collected from a sample group
Make predictions based on trends identified in  tables and graphs
Describe how scale can make graphs, tables  and charts appear misleading
Explain inferences made from statistical  information
Make inferences based on analysis of data  and interpretation of graphs
Select two points and approximate an  equation for the line of best fit (if  appropriate) for a set of data
Identify the trend of a set of data and  estimate the strength of the correlation  between two variables, e.g. strong vs.  weak, positive vs. negative
Given a set of data exhibiting a linear  trend, approximate an equation for the  line of best fit (with or without technology)  and use that model to make predictions

text: Standard 4: Students use concepts and tools of measurement to describe and quantify the world.

children.text: Measurable Attributes, Measurement Systems and Units
Name the days of the week in order
Tell time to the hour using digital and analog  clocks
Order pictures first, next, last based on time
Compare and order objects according to their  length or weight
Identify a penny, nickel and dime and state  the value of each.
Use the days of the week to show knowledge  of yesterday, today and tomorrow
Tell time to the hour and half-hour using digital  and analog clocks
Estimate and verify by measuring, length,  weight or capacity using nonstandard units
Estimate and verify by measuring, length to  the nearest inch, foot and centimeter
Identify a penny, nickel, dime and quarter and  state the value of each
Count a like set of pennies, nickels or dimes  to $1.00
Demonstrate that different combinations of  coins (i.e. pennies, nickels and dimes) can  have the same value
Sequence events with respect to time, e.g.  yesterday, today, tomorrow, seasons
Tell time to the nearest quarter hour and 5  minute interval using digital and analog clocks
Distinguish between week days and weekend  days
Recall the months of the year in order
Count mixed coins to $1.00
Estimate and measure weight to the nearest  pound or kilogram
Estimate and measure capacity to the nearest  cup or liter
Estimate and measure length to the nearest  inch, half-inch, foot or centimeter
Estimate and verify a quantity, e.g. marbles in a jar
Compare and order given lengths, capacities,  weights or temperatures that are expressed in  the same unit of measure
Identify the approximate size of basic units,  e.g. width of finger is about one centimeter,  large soda bottle is two liters, a paper clip  weighs one gram
Tell time to the nearest minute using digital  and analog clocks
Determine elapsed time by the hour
Count mixed coins and bills, i.e. $1, $5, $10,  $20
Read and measure temperature with a  thermometer using Fahrenheit and Celsius  scales
Estimate and measure to the nearest half inch  or centimeter
State specific relationships between units  within the same measuring system, e.g. hours  in a day, inches in a foot, cups in a pint
Estimate and measure perimeter, area and  volume using links, tiles, grid paper,  geoboards and dot paper
State specific relationships between units  within the same measuring system, e.g. feet  to yards, minutes to hours, milliliters to liters
Estimate and measure length to the nearest  quarter inch
Analyze relationships between perimeter and  area
Make change up to $20.00
Apply the concept of elapsed time, i.e.  schedules and calendars
Estimate and measure length to the nearest  eighth inch
Measure and apply elapsed time, i.e. time  zones, schedules and calendars
Measure angles using protractors
Estimate angle measures using the  benchmark angles 45°, 90°, 180°, 270° and  360°
Measure length to the nearest sixteenth of an  inch
Select an appropriate unit of measure, e.g.  What unit do you use to measure a person's  height?
Convert unit measurements within the same  system (metric and standard)
Distinguish among perimeter, area, surface  area and volume
Estimate a measurement to the degree of  precision that the tool provides
Convert unit measurements within the same  system (metric and standard) when solving  problems
Select the appropriate measure of perimeter,  area, surface area or volume to solve a  problem
Select an appropriate degree of precision  when using measurements for calculations
Compare unit measurements between  systems, e.g. a yard is almost a meter
Select appropriate units and scales for  problem situations involving measurement
Describe the effects of scalar change on  the area and volume of a figure, e.g. the  effect of doubling one or more edges of a  solid on its surface area and volume
Use approximations to compare the  standard and metric systems of  measurement, e.g. a five-kilometer race  is about three miles long
Given a conversion factor, convert  between standard and metric  measurements
Measurement Tools, Techniques, and Formulas
Measure length with non-standard units, e.g.  paper clips, cubes
Identify the appropriate tool used to measure  length (i.e. ruler), weight (i.e. scale) time (i.e.  clock, calendar) and temperature (i.e.  thermometer)
Select the appropriate units for measuring  time, length, weight and temperature
Use the symbols for the dollar and cent
Select a variety of tools for measuring length,  weight and capacity
Select appropriate units for measuring  perimeter, area and volume
Select and use appropriate units when  measuring length, area and volume
Use formulas to calculate the perimeter and  area of squares and rectangles
Use formulas to calculate the volume of  rectangular prisms
Select appropriate tools and units to determine  the measurements needed for calculating  perimeter, circumference, area, surface area  and volume
Use formulas to determine the circumference  and area of circles and the perimeter and area  of triangles and parallelograms
Use area formulas to determine the surface  area of right prisms and square pyramids
Use formulas to determine the volume of  rectangular prisms
Select and use appropriate tools and units to  determine the measurements needed for  calculating perimeter, circumference, area,  surface area and volume
Solve problems involving scale factors, using  ratio and proportion
Use formulas to determine the perimeter and  area of trapezoids
Use area formulas to determine the surface  area of right cylinders
Use formulas to determine the volume of right  cylinders
Determine the area of irregularly-shaped  objects
Use formulas to determine the surface area  and volume of right cones and spheres
Use methods necessary to achieve a  specified degree of precision and  accuracy (i.e. appropriate number of  significant digits) in measurement  situations
Employ estimation techniques to evaluate  reasonableness of results in  measurement situations
Use unit analysis to track units during  computations
Given a formula list, compute the area of  a regular polygon
Given a formula list, compute the surface  area and volume of a right prism, right  cylinder, right pyramid, right cone and  sphere

Apply indirect measurement techniques to  solve problems involving irregular shapes  or inaccessible objects, e.g. calculate the  distance across a lake, triangulate an  irregular region to find its approximate  area

text: Standard 5: Students use algebraic concepts, functions, patterns, and relationships to solve problems.

children.text: Patterns, Relations, and Functions
Identify, sort and classify objects by one  attribute
Recognize, extend and describe simple  patterns
Identify, sort and classify objects by two or  more attributes
Recognize, extend, create and describe  patterns
Extend and create number patterns
State the rule that describes a given repeating  and growing pattern
Use patterns to solve problems
Create patterns using multiplication
Determine the missing elements of a pattern of  multiples
Determine the missing elements of complex  repeating patterns
Analyze patterns represented by tables and  graphs
Identify a rule for a pattern involving addition,  subtraction or multiplication
Identify the rule for a pattern and then use the  rule to solve a problem
Identify and describe patterns represented by  tables, graphs and sequences
Create tables and graphs to analyze and  describe patterns
Extend numerical patterns, e.g. Pascal's  triangle and the Fibonacci sequence
Given the explicit and/or the recursive  definition of a sequence, generate a  specific term (explicit formula only) or a  specified number of terms
Express relations and functions using a  variety of representations, i.e. numeric,  graphic, symbolic and verbal
Determine whether a relation is a function  by examining various representations of  the relation, e.g. table, graph, equation,  set of ordered pairs
Perform the operations of addition,  subtraction, multiplication, and division on  algebraic functions, e.g. given f(x) = 2x  and g(x) = 5x – 7, find f(x) + g(x)
Identify the independent variable,  dependent variable, domain and range of  a function

Draw graphs of linear and quadratic  functions using paper and pencil, labeling  key features, e.g. graph a line and label  its x-intercept and y-intercept, graph a  parabola and label its vertex and one  point on each side of the vertex
Perform advanced operations (i.e.  composition and finding inverses) on  algebraic functions
Generate graphs of a variety of functions  (i.e. linear, quadratic, polynomial,  absolute value and exponential), using  technology when appropriate
Numeric and Algebraic Representations
Demonstrate the commutative property of  addition, e.g. 3 + 5 = 5 + 3
Solve addition and subtraction equations with  unknown numbers, e.g. 2 + i = 5
Solve addition, subtraction, multiplication, and  division equations with unknown numbers,  e.g. 8 x i = 56
Explain that variables represent unknowns
Identify a variable in an expression
Use a variable to represent an unknown  quantity
Create algebraic expressions and equations to  represent word phrases and sentences
Apply the order of operations and the  commutative, associative and distributive  properties to evaluate numeric expressions
Use inverse operations and properties of  equality to solve one-step equations and  inequalities in one variable
Use variables, expressions and equations to  represent problem situations
Apply the order of operations and the  commutative, associative and distributive  properties to simplify algebraic expressions
Apply inverse operations and the properties of  equality to solve multi-step equations and  inequalities in one variable

Develop algebraic expressions,  equations or inequalities involving one or  two variables to represent relationships  (e.g. given a verbal statement, write an  equivalent algebraic expression or  equation) found in various contexts (e.g.  time and distance problems, mixture  problems)
Manipulate algebraic expressions and  equations using properties of real  numbers, e.g. simplify, factor
Solve linear equations and inequalities,  systems of two linear equations or  inequalities and quadratic equations  having rational solutions, e.g. factoring,  quadratic formula
Solve linear equations and inequalities,  systems of two linear equations or  inequalities and quadratic equations  having rational solutions, e.g. factoring,  quadratic formula
Solve quadratic equations involving  complex roots
Use transformations (i.e. reflection,  translation, dilation) to graph linear,  quadratic and absolute value functions
Given the graph of a transformed linear,  quadratic or absolute value function, write  its equation
Mathematical Modeling
Use tools and strategies (e.g. manipulatives)  to model problems
Use symbols (i.e. +, -, =, <, >) to write simple  number sentences
Use words, objects and number sentences to  represent addition and subtraction problems
Use symbols to write number sentences, i.e.  +, -, >, <, =, x and ÷
Solve problems with variables
Use parentheses in solving simple equations
Use equations to solve problems, e.g. 28/x = 7
Use representations to solve problems, i.e.  tables and numerical sentences
Write one-step equations and inequalities to  represent problem situations
Write multi-step equations and inequalities to  represent problem situations
Use essential quantitative relationships in  a situation to determine whether the  relationship can be modeled by a linear  function, e.g. simple interest is linear,  compound interest is not linear
Graphically represent the solution or  solutions to an equation, inequality or  system
Interpret a graphical representation of a  real-world situation
Draw conclusions about a situation being  modeled
Determine and write an equation for a  function (i.e. linear, quadratic, polynomial,  absolute value and exponential) that  models a mathematical relationship
Rates of Change
Recognize examples of change over time,  e.g. growth of a sixth grader from September  to May
Graph change over time, e.g. growth,  distance, population
Solve problems involving rates, i.e. speed  equals distance divided by time (miles per  hour)
Approximate and interpret rates of change  from graphical and numerical data
